IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: A TRADE ASSOCIATION ORGANIZED TO ASSIST, INFORM, & EDUCATE ITS MEMBERS WHO CONSIST OF COMMERCIAL BANKS, THRIFT INSTITUTIONS & TRUST COMPANIES IN TENNESSEE.
IRS990.MissionDesc: THE MISSION OF THE TENNESSEE BANKERS ASSOCIATION IS TO REPRESENT AND SUPPORT ITS MEMBERS, ENABLING THEM TO PROVIDE A FULL RANGE OF QUALITY FINANCIAL PRODUCTS AND SERVICES WHILE MAINTAINING SAFETY AND SOUNDNESS.
IRS990.Desc: The Tennessee Bankers Association (TBA) is a trade association established to serve the needs of the state's banks, thrift institutions, and trust companies. Among other activities, the Association provides continuing education, develops and monitors state and federal legislative agendas, disseminates information on all facets of the financial services industry, and promotes the public image of financial institutions. Each year, the TBA conducts approximately 70 information, education, and training programs. Among these are the TBA Annual Meeting, Independent Bankers Division Convention, and the TBA Leadership Convention, held annually. The TBA conducts three banking schools-The Southeastern Schools of Banking, Commercial Lending, and Consumer Lending. These schools enroll students from around the Southeast and enjoy the endorsement of several other southeastern bankers associations. As today's financial industry grows, changes, and faces new challenges, so does the Tennessee Bankers Association. The TBA continually strives to evaluate, improve, and increase its programs and services to meet the needs of its member institutions.

OtherAssetsOrgGrp.Desc: CASH SURRENDER VALUE OF OFFICER LIFE INSURANCE

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule D, Part X, Line 2 FIN 48 (ASC 740) footnote
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Association follows generally accepted accounting principles with respect to accounting for uncertainty in income taxes. Under the guidance, a tax position is recognized as a benefit only if it is "more likely than not" that the tax position would be sustained in a tax examination, with a tax examination being presumed to occur. The amount recognized is the largest amount of tax benefit that is greater than 50% likely of being realized on examination. For tax positions not meeting the "more likely than not" test, no tax benefit is recorded. The Association does not expect the total amount of unrecognized tax benefits to significantly change in the next 12 months. The Association recognized interest and/or penalties related to income tax matters in income tax expense. The Association did not have any amounts accrued for interest and penalties at April 30, 2022 and 2021.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a Travel for companions
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Travel for companions: Senior Management and Board Members are provided travel for companions when there is deemed to be a bonafide business purpose which benefits the association. The expenses are reimbursed to the employee and/or board member once proper substantiation has been remitted. These payments are not taxable compensation to the employee or board member.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a Tax indemnification and gross-up payments
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Tax Indemnification and gross-up payments: Employee Christmas Bonuses are distributed to all employees and taxable to the recipient and grossed up for FICA and Medicare taxes.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 4b Supplemental nonqualified retirement plan
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Collin Barrett, Stacy Langford, Angela Griffin, and Amy Heaslet participated in a nonqualified deferred compensation plan. No distributions were made to plan participants during the tax year. Accrued Deferred Compensation amounts are as follows: Collin Barrett: $35,000 Stacy Langford: $15,000 Angela Griffin: $ 25,000 Amy Heaslet: $20,000

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 1a Delegate broad authority to a committee
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: There shall be an Executive Committee of the Board of Directors composed of the Chairman, Immediate Past Chairman, the Chairman elect, the Vice Chairman, and the President. The Executive Committee shall have charge of the general business and financial affairs of the Association when the Board of Directors is not in session. The Executive Committee may meet upon the call of the Chairman or President of the Association, and the attendance of three members of this committee shall constitute a quorum. This committee shall make a full report of all official actions taken.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 2 Family/business relationships amongst interested persons
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: COLLIN B. BARRETT and ANGELA D. GRIFFIN - Business relationship

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 6 Classes of members or stockholders
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Tennessee Bankers Association has 2 classes of members: (1) Regular and (2) Associate. The members (or their delegates) may attend membership meetings and vote and participate in the business of such meetings. The Chairman, Chairman-elect, and Vice Chairman shall be elected by the regular members at the annual meeting. In addition, the bylaws may be amended and voted on by the delegates at the annual meeting.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 7a Members or stockholders electing members of governing body
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Members have the right to voice vote in election matters at the annual meeting. The Tennessee Bankers Association has 2 classes of members: (1) Regular and (2) Associate. The by-laws may be amended at any annual meeting or by a written ballot by a vote of two thirds of the delegates present or a majority of the voting power, whichever is less, notice of the proposed amendment having been first submitted to the secretary.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 7b Decisions requiring approval by members or stockholders
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Chairman, Chairman Elect, and Vice-Chairman shall be elected by the regular members at the annual meeting for a period of one year and shall serve until their successors are elected.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 11b Review of form 990 by governing body
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: THE FORM 990 AND ALL RELATED SCHEDULES ARE REVIEWED BY THE CFO, PRESIDENT, AND EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE OF THE TENNESSEE BANKERS ASSOCIATION BOARD OF DIRECTORS PRIOR TO FILING IT WITH THE IRS. An electronic copy of the final Form 990 is provided to all members of the organization's governing body prior to filing with the IRS.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 12c Conflict of interest policy
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The board of directors, officers, and key employees must review and sign a written copy of the conflict of interest policy on an annual basis. Senior management reviews for conflict disclosures and none have been disclosed, suspected, or discovered. Should there be the possibility of a conflict, the conflict may be resolved by having the director disclose to the chairman, and, if necessary the entire board, the possibility and nature of the conflict. After disclosure, the board member may participate in a discussion on the issue. However, the director should abstain in any vote on the matter. In order to assure compliance with the provisions of this policy, it is the duty of every director, officer, and employee to bring to the attention of the appropriate board member, senior officer, or supervisor, any violation or possible violation of this policy. It is the further duty of the person so notified to communicate the violation or potential violation to the president, or if the violation is by the president, to the chairman of the board, who shall institute an investigation of such violation or potential violation. A violation of this policy shall, at the discretion of the board, result in the suspension or termination of the director, officer, or employee involved.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 15a Process to establish compensation of top management official
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The compensation of the President is reviewed by the compensation committee and voted on by the full board of directors. Salary surveys are utilized and sent to the compensation committee and full board for approval, and contemporaneous documentation is performed with regard to these transactions. This process was undertaken in FY 2022.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 15b Process to establish compensation of other employees
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The compensation of other officers and key employees is reviewed by the compensation committee and voted on by the full board of directors. Salary surveys are utilized and sent to the compensation committee and full board for approval, and contemporaneous documentation is performed with regard to these transactions. This process was undertaken in FY 2022.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 19 Required documents available to the public
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Governing documents, conflict of interest policies, and financial statements are not required disclosures pursuant to Internal Revenue Code (IRC) Section 6104. These documents are not available to the public at this time.
